image.altText: A truck drives out of the entrance of the Darwin Port on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The Chinese-controlled Port of Darwin has signed a "friendly cooperation" agreement with Shenzhen Port in southern China, citing a wish to establish a closer relationship and examine business opportunities.

title.children: Darwin Port increases 'friendly cooperation' with China in new deal

image.altText: An elderly man wearing a military hat and war medals.

props.synopsis: Glenn Dobie served Australia during World War II, but his friends and family later discovered he never received the recognition he was entitled to.

title.children: World War II veteran receives missing service medals nearly 80 years later

image.altText: A close up of a bald man wearing a striped shirt standing in his garage.

props.synopsis: Soaring power bills and plunging incentives for excess solar power are pushing more Australian households into installing home energy storage. Yet these batteries are still very expensive and don't stack up for many.

title.children: 'There's a supply glut': The problem with solar feed-in tariffs

image.altText: A composite of Kamala Harris and Cate Blanchet.

props.synopsis: Across Australia, households on six figure incomes are struggling to pay the rent or mortgages – let alone afford little luxuries. Others are delaying retirement or working extra jobs to pay the bills.

title.children: High earners like Kamala Harris and Cate Blanchett call themselves middle class, but are they?

image.altText: Mid shot of a woman and a man addressing the media.

props.synopsis: Against warnings from health, justice and Aboriginal groups, the NT government says it will fulfil its election promise and return the age of criminal responsibility back to 10 this year.

title.children: 'It's going to scar them': NT to become first jurisdiction to lower criminal age of responsibility

image.altText: The front façade of a prison at dusk

props.synopsis: Western Australian taxpayers aren't getting bang for their buck in the area of youth justice, but it's children who are paying the highest price.

title.children: Here's why not investing in youth justice is costing taxpayers more and making everyone less safe

image.altText: The top of a Royal Hobart Hospital building with out of focus tree foliage in the foreground

props.synopsis: As Tasmania's health system continues to face critical staffing issues, the government has ramped up its reliance on locums — who are paid more, but have fewer workplace entitlements.

title.children: Locums help to 'fill gaps' in the health system. Tasmania's spend on them tripled in three years

image.altText: A pub at night time

props.synopsis: Twenty-one years ago, the tiny town of Ultima set out to boost its population by 25 per cent within a year at a cost of just $12.

title.children: This tiny Australian town sold abandoned plots of land for $1 to boost its dwindling population

image.altText: A protest outside the State Library of Victoria

props.synopsis: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators are marching in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide as the first anniversary of the October 7 attack looms.

title.children: Thousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators march through Sydney and Melbourne

image.altText: new beirut smoke

props.synopsis: Five Israeli strikes hit south Beirut and its outskirts on Saturday evening with four of them "very violent", according to official Lebanese media.

title.children: Five Israeli strikes hit south Beirut, four of them 'very violent', Lebanese media says

image.altText: A child sits next to a sandy crater

props.synopsis: With the first anniversary of the October 7 attacks on Israel looming, we ask a wide range of experts in the Middle East how the current crisis ends.

title.children: 'A genuine turning point in the Middle East': A year after the October 7 attacks, everything has changed

image.altText: Wong, Marles and Albanese stand at lecterns in a courtyard speaking.

props.synopsis: The defence minister says Israel is entitled to respond to Iranian strikes but there should be a de-escalation to avoid adding to the "totally unacceptable" death toll in Gaza and Lebanon.

title.children: Marles says Israel has right to respond to Iran but urges de-escalation amid scramble to get thousands of Australians out of Lebanon

image.altText: Two men wave at the camera as they walk off a flight in Cyprus

props.synopsis: The first two Australian government charter flights land in the Mediterranean island to help Australian citizens, permanent residents and their family members flee the worsening conflict in Lebanon.

title.children: 'Lucky to be Australian': Hundreds of Australians arrive in Cyprus on flights from Lebanon

image.altText: Departure/arrival signs at the entrance to Melbourne Airport.

props.synopsis: Assistant Minister for Immigration Matt Thistlethwaite has offered a scathing assessment of Australia's approach to immigration. A lot rides on the government's efforts to re-establish bipartisanship, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Immigration has provided 'marginal economic benefit', says the assistant minister. A lot rides on what happens next

image.altText: Fatima Payman quits Labor

props.synopsis: WA senator Fatima Payman, who resigned from Labor to sit as an independent, is set to announce the formation of a new political party targeting progressive voters in every state and territory.

title.children: Former Labor senator Fatima Payman to announce new political party

image.altText: Trumpie

props.synopsis: Donald Trump returns to Pennsylvania, where he was nearly assassinated in July, holding a rally with heightened security and guest Elon Musk.

title.children: 'We've bled together': Trump returns to site of Pennsylvania assassination attempt with Elon Musk

image.altText: A sinking ship.

props.synopsis: New Zealand says it has rescued all 75 crew and passengers from a wrecked navy vessel that ran aground and sank off Samoa while conducting a reef survey.

title.children: New Zealand navy ship runs aground and sinks off Samoa

image.altText: Women in blue suits dance on documents with red signs

props.synopsis: The female artist behind the "women only" lounge at the centre of a discrimination complaint from a man who was refused entry says the space at Hobart's Mona will close.

title.children: 'No men allowed' ladies lounge to close as artist declares Mona artwork has 'run its course'

image.altText: A home has been destroyed by fire.

props.synopsis: An eight-year-old girl dies and a woman is missing, feared dead, after a large fire at a unit complex east of Brisbane.

title.children: Girl killed, woman missing after suburban house fire

image.altText: A five year old girl being hugged passionately by her mother

props.synopsis: On a quiet October day in 1972, Victoria Police faced the unthinkable when six students and a teacher were kidnapped from a country school. Now one of the survivors is sharing her story.

title.children: 'Crime of the century' survivor breaks silence 52 years after Faraday school kidnapping

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson with his eyebrows raised and mouth open. The Hard Quiz logo is in the top right corner

props.synopsis: Oh, you won a trivia night once? Cute. Now it’s time to play … HARD!

title.children: You think you know it all? Don’t be shy now. Let’s play … HARD!

image.altText: A pink sign that reads "Crumbl Cookies Launch This Sunday 29/9/2024"

props.synopsis: Australian fans of a US cookie with a cult following flew to Hawaii, bought hundreds of baked goods, and re-sold them in Sydney. Customers who feel "scammed" are questioning how what they did is legal.

title.children: Customers of unofficial Crumbl cookie pop-up feel 'scammed', but what organisers did may be legal

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: An adult and a child are dead after a buggy carrying four people rolled at a private property at Tubbut, in Victoria's east.

title.children: Two people killed in buggy rollover in Victoria's east

image.altText: Suchita Smith poses for a photo on a tree-lined board walk, wearing a red floral dress and black cardigan

props.synopsis: Suchita Smith was born with a degenerative condition that leads to short stature and badly-formed joints, causing significant chronic pain. But she loves to dance — and as physical limitations have taken hold, she has learnt to find other ways to do it.

title.children: Just standing up hurts and she's losing her ability to talk. But Suchita Smith is insistent on joy

image.altText: Joseph-Aukuso Sua'ali'i looks to his left during a 2023 NRL match.

props.synopsis: Rugby Australia is hoping Joseph-Aukuso Sua'ali'i's code switch will help it retain its star juniors, however a cashed-up NRL will make no apologies in its recruitment efforts, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: Signing Sua'ali'i and a league legend's son gives rugby a boost, but NRL is set to keep dominating code war

image.altText: Wide show of Ratcliffe coal plant, with fence and coal yard in the foreground and plant and power lines in the background

props.synopsis: More than 150 years after pioneering the technology, the UK has shut its last coal-fired power station. Experts say it's a seminal moment for the energy transition.

title.children: The birthplace of the industrial revolution is done with coal. What does that tell the rest of the world?

image.altText: A woman with a brown ponytail, jeans and a tshirt stands in front of a freshly painted white and cream Queenslander-style pub

props.synopsis: A historic Queensland hotel which was gutted by fire in 2015 is reopening today thanks to the vision of one enterprising couple who took a chance on country hospitality.

title.children: When Nicole bought her first country pub she 'couldn't even pour a beer' — now she owns three

image.altText: A yacht sittin in mud at a mooring

props.synopsis: A glitzy marina resort promised an idyllic lifestyle with everything tropical Queensland had to offer, but successive natural and corporate disasters have dashed those dreams. Could a solution be on the horizon?

title.children: How coastal town's tropical dream became a mud-choked nightmare

image.altText: A woman with blue hair sits at a park.

props.synopsis: Cheryl Rowe never thought she'd spend two years living in a tent, worrying during every winter storm that her shelter would collapse on top of her again.

title.children: At 65, Cheryl has spent the winter 'digging trenches' to stop her tent from flooding

image.altText: backyard fence on surburban property

props.synopsis: While generally it is up to neighbours to split the cost of the build, repair, or replacement of a shared fence, it's not always as simple as splitting it down the middle.

title.children: 'It doesn't have to be split equally': Who pays when building or repairing a shared fence?

image.altText: Burnie woodchip pile supplied by Nearmap, taken on Feb 4 2024

props.synopsis: The woodchip pile has been in place for decades, and the idea of shifting it may have never crossed the mind of locals.

title.children: The 'Pyramids of Burnie' are a local icon, but some people think they should be shifted

image.altText: An elderly man in a high-vis work shirt leaning on timber frame of his verandah.

props.synopsis: Through mining booms and busts, the Kalgoorlie Nickel Smelter in Western Australia has operated continuously since 1973. But workers are now being stood down as BHP prepares to place its Nickel West division on care and maintenance.

title.children: Graeme reluctantly hangs up his high-vis as nickel smelter marks 'end of an era'

image.altText: Vineyards damaged by frost.

props.synopsis: As crop growers across the country's south-east come to grips with the fallout from last month's unseasonally freezing overnight temperatures, there are calls for the event to be treated as a natural disaster in order to trigger urgent government assistance.

title.children: 'Like a blowtorch': From above, the frost impact on vineyards is obvious
